results.title: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune

video_links.name: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune

results.brief_description: An aging astronomer invites students to his castle observatory to observe a solar eclipse. Amid the childish pranks of the novice astronomers and the wondrous vision of the eclipse, George Melies, cinema’s great magician, weaves numerous amusing set pieces. Much to the astronomer’s excitement, the sun and the moon flirt with each other as they come together in an astronomical courtship and the sky explodes in a dance of female stars. On earth, the astronomer falls prey to his cheeky students who rob him of his stately dignity, while the heavens smile down on him from above.

On earth, the astronomer falls prey to his cheeky students who rob him of his stately dignity, while the heavens smile down on him from above.

results.title: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)

video_links.name: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)

results.brief_description: Melies’ fantastical vision of life on the moon.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

results.title_for_label: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)
results.description: One of the first Science Fiction films, this Melies’ short humorously proposes what man discovers when he first lands on the moon. Based on the Jules Verne story, George Melies used his extraordinary cinematic illusions to tell this story of the first voyage to the moon. Made in 1902, this was a visionary film that has come to be recognised as a cinematic masterpiece. Among the many comical set pieces is the famous scene in which a rocket ship crash-lands into the eye of the ‘man in the moon’. This whimsical fantasy is also exemplary in its early depiction of the moon and the possible encounters between humans and worlds beyond our imagining, in our exploration of deep space.
description_for_label: One of the first Science Fiction films, this Melies’ short humorously proposes what man discovers when he first lands on the moon. Based on the Jules Verne story, George Melies used his extraordinary cinematic illusions to tell this story of the first voyage to the moon. Made in 1902, this was a visionary film that has come to be recognised as a cinematic masterpiece. Among the many comical set pieces is the famous scene in which a rocket ship crash-lands into the eye of the ‘man in the moon’. This whimsical fantasy is also exemplary in its early depiction of the moon and the possible encounters between humans and worlds beyond our imagining, in our exploration of deep space.

results.title: K-Rad Man
results.brief_description: A Mad Scientist creates the ultimate computer virus and locates a suitable test subject: K-Rad Man - to whom he can expose the computer virus and gauge its results.
results.description: A Mad Scientist creates the ultimate computer virus and locates a suitable test subject: K-Rad Man - to whom he can expose the computer virus and gauge its results.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip to Papua New Guinea in 1961. The filmmaker captures a seaside town, fishing boats, people at a market and men in traditional headdresses, as well as the Boumana (Bomana) War Cemetery in Port Moresby.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:27:00 fishing boats by the sea
00:02:05:00 group of women sitting around talking
00:03:19:00 young child
00:04:21:00 boats in the bay
00:05:21:00 sign for ‘Boumana War Cemetery’
00:06:45:00 views across a valley
00:07:04:00 a waterfall
00:09:05:00 men in headdresses
00:09:16:00 a polo game with locals watching
00:10:57:00 views over the bay
00:12:44:00 girls playing a ball game
00:13:15:00 man fixing a small boat
00:14:00:00 a traffic warden in the middle of an intersection
00:15:16:00 views from an aeroplane

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film showcases Papua New Guinea (PNG) in the 1960s. It begins with coastal towns and ports, sighing, canoes and boats and then travels by plane to the ‘Highlands’ on what appears to be a cargo plane. Along the way, Wallace captures the villages, the dramatic landscapes and the various peoples of PNG.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a group of smiling children walk along a road under palm trees
00:00:25:00 thatched houses facing a lagoon
00:01:45:00 taking down the sail on a local ‘outrigger canoe’
00:02:18:00 view from a plane overhead and a TAA (Trans Australia Airlines) plane on an airfield being emptied of cargo
00:02:32:00 several totem sculptures and carved statues
00:02:57:00 a man spearing fish in the waves off a rocky perch
00:03:09:00 Coastwatchers Memorial in Madang
00:03:18:00 ‘Petrus II’ sailing boat and unloading cargo of cacao beans in large hessian sacks from a boat onto a pier
00:03:54:00 a lovely old rusty shed, jetty and boats in a palm tree setting
00:04:04:00 school girls playing sport
00:04:29:00 fixing a car in a village of thatch covered houses
00:05:04:00 canoes being paddled across the water
00:06:07:00 a larger boat followed by scenes around a portside town
00:07:34:00 a particularly picturesque roadside store, Central Merchants, and people carrying goods on shoulders and heads
00:08:34:00 ‘44 gallon drums’ being unloaded from a plane by being bounced onto a large rubber tyre
00:08:54:00 aeriel views over the jungles and mountains and misty clouds
00:09:24:00 a long winding river being filmed from the plane above
00:11:29:00 boarding a TAA plane and takeoff with the mountains in the background
00:12:04:00 a small yellow plane
00:12:08:00 a village with thatched houses
00:12:50:00 small planes
00:13:00:00 traditional dress
00:13:23:00 flying over mountains and looking at roads criss-crossing the terrain
00:19:38:00 traditional grass mat weaving
00:21:53:00 sign ‘Kainantu Mile High Gateway to the Highlands Alt. 5280’
00:22:21:00 a large river system from overhead
00:22:10:00 a signpost for ‘Mumeng’, ‘Bulolo’ and ‘Wau’
00:23:38:00 lush valleys in the Highlands
00:25:44:00 sign ‘You are now approaching Wau, Top of Drome, Elvn 3200’
00:28:58:00 house in the trees
00:29:11:00 people washing clothes in the river
00:30:10:00 a cemetery and white crucifix monuments
00:31:04:00 TAA plane

results.title: [Unidentified 16mm Film]

video_links.name: Uncredited footage, circa 1945, performances and parade.

results.brief_description: Film contains silent footage of various vaudeville and circus-style performances including dancing, acrobatics, slapstick comedy and more. The film also includes extensive footage of the British Navy marching in a street parade in Melbourne. One shot appears to be Elizabeth Street, featuring trams and the Flinders Street Station clocktower.
results.description: Film contains silent footage of various vaudeville and circus-style performances including dancing, acrobatics, slapstick comedy and more. The film also includes extensive footage of the British Navy marching in a street parade in Melbourne. One shot appears to be Elizabeth Street, featuring trams and the Flinders Street Station clocktower.
description_for_label: Film contains silent footage of various vaudeville and circus-style performances including dancing, acrobatics, slapstick comedy and more. The film also includes extensive footage of the British Navy marching in a street parade in Melbourne. One shot appears to be Elizabeth Street, featuring trams and the Flinders Street Station clocktower.

production_dates.notes: Based on the HMAS King George V seen in this film docked in Melbourne.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’, ‘The Victorian Alps’
00:00:50:00 views from the road and a small old house
00:01:06:00 sign ‘Alpine Road’ with lots of information for the traveller
00:01:25:00 sign ‘You are now entering Mount Hotham Alpine Reserve’
00:01:35:00 looking across a corner of a dirt road high up in the mountains
00:02:22:00 roads, signs and aerials on top of the mountains and a melting snowman
00:02:58:00 brass sundial
00:04:46:00 sign warning to ‘keep to the left of the poles’ and directional sign to ‘Hotham, Diamentina, Harrietville’
00:05:20:00 chair lift pulley station and 1970s style four wheel drive vehicle, a chalet and hamlet
00:05:55:00 a small A-frame chalet or hut
00:06:30:00 views of roads, trees and cars with the mountains in the background
00:07:05:00 two purple swamp hens (common to wetlands or rivers of Eastern Australia)
00:07:50:00 signs ‘Mount Buffalo’ and ‘Eurobin Falls’ followed by views of cascading waters over rocky embankments and cliffs
00:08:30:00 sign ‘Mackeys Lookout’ followed by views out over the valleys below including cars negotiating the tight turns on the roads winding down the mountain
00:09:08:00 sign ‘Rollarson’s Falls’
00:09:35:00 hikers negotiate logs and rocks along the path
00:10:16:00 a long narrow waterfall into a lovely natural rock pool
00:11:00:00 looking out over misty valleys through an old walk bridge
00:13:08:00 a narrow waterfall in a rocky cliffface
00:13:36:00 snow along the sides of the road
00:14:26:00 sign ‘Toownag Gap, Mt Buffalo, Mt Bogong’ and a visitor looking through binoculars from a lookout
00:14:46:00 looking down from a higher vantage spot on a long windy road through the mountains toward a township beyond
00:15:20:00 views of electricity towers across the ranges
00:15:50:00 sign ‘Pretty Valley Branch East Kiewa River’
00:16:11:00 sign ‘rocky Valley Dam’ and scenes around the dam
00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township

00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township
description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’, ‘The Victorian Alps’
00:00:50:00 views from the road and a small old house
00:01:06:00 sign ‘Alpine Road’ with lots of information for the traveller
00:01:25:00 sign ‘You are now entering Mount Hotham Alpine Reserve’
00:01:35:00 looking across a corner of a dirt road high up in the mountains
00:02:22:00 roads, signs and aerials on top of the mountains and a melting snowman
00:02:58:00 brass sundial
00:04:46:00 sign warning to ‘keep to the left of the poles’ and directional sign to ‘Hotham, Diamentina, Harrietville’
00:05:20:00 chair lift pulley station and 1970s style four wheel drive vehicle, a chalet and hamlet
00:05:55:00 a small A-frame chalet or hut
00:06:30:00 views of roads, trees and cars with the mountains in the background
00:07:05:00 two purple swamp hens (common to wetlands or rivers of Eastern Australia)
00:07:50:00 signs ‘Mount Buffalo’ and ‘Eurobin Falls’ followed by views of cascading waters over rocky embankments and cliffs
00:08:30:00 sign ‘Mackeys Lookout’ followed by views out over the valleys below including cars negotiating the tight turns on the roads winding down the mountain
00:09:08:00 sign ‘Rollarson’s Falls’
00:09:35:00 hikers negotiate logs and rocks along the path
00:10:16:00 a long narrow waterfall into a lovely natural rock pool
00:11:00:00 looking out over misty valleys through an old walk bridge
00:13:08:00 a narrow waterfall in a rocky cliffface
00:13:36:00 snow along the sides of the road
00:14:26:00 sign ‘Toownag Gap, Mt Buffalo, Mt Bogong’ and a visitor looking through binoculars from a lookout
00:14:46:00 looking down from a higher vantage spot on a long windy road through the mountains toward a township beyond
00:15:20:00 views of electricity towers across the ranges
00:15:50:00 sign ‘Pretty Valley Branch East Kiewa River’
00:16:11:00 sign ‘rocky Valley Dam’ and scenes around the dam
00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township

results.title: Bayi Gardiya (Singing Desert)
results.credit_line:
Creative technology studio: Nakatomi
Performed by Christian Thompson
Composed by Christian Thompson and Mark Mitchell
Sound production by Mark Mitchell at Electric Dreams Studio
With special thanks to Rachael Sheridan, Jeanette Little and Leyla Varela
results.material_description: 360 degree video, VR system, headphones, sand and AIATSIS map of Indigenous Australia
results.brief_description:
Bayi Gardiya (Singing Desert) is an immersive, 360 degree moving image and sound experience.

The environment within Bayi Gardiya situates a visitor in the creek bed of The Sixth Mile, Barcaline, western Queensland. The imagery and sound within transforms from morning to midday and then to twilight and night. These transitions also shift through seasonal change to represent and also comment on the impacts of Global Warming on the fragile, semi-desert Hinterland and country represented in the work.

results.title: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.credit_line:
Jason Phu
Three-channel video installation, 85 mins.
Edited by Conor Bateman
Mordant Family Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.brief_description: During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life.

constellations_primary.name: Jason Phu and genre-bending kung fu films
constellations_primary.description: Analects of Kung Phu work is a philosophical guide to life via martial arts films, drawing on his interest in Vietnamese and Chinese folklore, which inspires many of the films featured in this Constellation.

results.title_for_label: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.description:
“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like Drunken Master (1978) and Avatar the Last Airbender (2005–08), Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s Dao De Jing, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales.

Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.

Read more

More than 200 kung fu films later, Jason Phu had his own movie to make by Kerrie O’Brien

My parents met at the fish market by Jason Phu in The Lifted Brow

Interview #34 — Jason Phu by Sophia Cai in Liminal

Storytelling with Jason Phu by Sabina McKenna in Acclaim

Who is Jason Phu? by Jane Albert in Broadsheet

results.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
results.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

constellations_primary.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_primary.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.description:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
description_for_label:

But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
